stem: Based on the findings, which action should the nurse take FIRST?

options.text: Immediately elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees and loosen any tight clothing.
Administer PRN acetaminophen 650 mg PO for headache.
Check the patency of the indwelling urinary catheter and irrigate if necessary.
Notify the healthcare provider to obtain an order for an antihypertensive medication.

tabs.content: S: Mr. Jones, a 62-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury, is reporting a severe headache and feeling flushed. He is diaphoretic above the level of his injury. His last bowel movement was three days ago. B: He has a history of autonomic dysreflexia. He has a chronic indwelling urinary catheter due to neurogenic bladder. He usually manages his bowel program every other day with digital stimulation. A: His blood pressure is 210/110 mmHg, heart rate is 52 bpm. He is restless and anxious, rating his headache as 8/10. I auscultated clear lung sounds bilaterally. His skin is pale and cool below the level of injury. 14:15: Notified Dr. Smith with the above information. R: I recommend immediately addressing the potential autonomic dysreflexia by elevating his head, checking his catheter for patency, and assessing for any other potential triggers. I will continue to monitor his vital signs every 5 minutes. Will need orders for BP management and bowel management.
14:10: BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 52 bpm, RR 18, SpO2 98% on room air, Temp 99.2°F (37.3°C)

Patient reports severe headache (8/10). Skin is flushed and diaphoretic above the level of injury (T6). Skin is pale and cool below the level of injury. Auscultation reveals clear lung sounds bilaterally. Patient is restless and anxious.
No current orders related to blood pressure management or bowel management.
PRN acetaminophen 650 mg PO q4h for headache. Last dose given 6 hours ago.

rationale.correct: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency characterized by an abrupt onset of excessively high blood pressure, bradycardia, and other autonomic symptoms. The FIRST action is to elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees to promote orthostatic hypotension and reduce blood pressure. Loosening tight clothing can also help reduce external stimuli that may be exacerbating the condition. This immediate intervention aims to decrease the patient's blood pressure rapidly and prevent complications such as stroke or seizure.
rationale.incorrect: Administering acetaminophen addresses the symptom of headache but does not treat the underlying cause of autonomic dysreflexia and is a lower priority. Checking the catheter patency is an important step in identifying and addressing a potential cause of autonomic dysreflexia but is secondary to immediately reducing the blood pressure. Notifying the healthcare provider is essential, but it should occur concurrently with or immediately after implementing initial interventions to lower blood pressure. Waiting for an order before taking any action delays critical treatment.

answerBreakdown.explanation: Immediate elevation of the head reduces BP; loosening clothing reduces external stimuli.
Addresses headache symptom only; does not treat cause.
Important, but secondary to immediate BP reduction.
Delays immediate treatment; initial interventions should be implemented first.

clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention to prevent severe complications.
Elevating the head of the bed is the first-line intervention to reduce blood pressure in patients experiencing autonomic dysreflexia.
Always assess for and remove any potential triggers, such as tight clothing or a full bladder.

questionTrap.trap: Many options seem reasonable, but the question asks for the FIRST action, emphasizing the need to prioritize interventions that directly and immediately address the life-threatening hypertension.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on interventions that will have the most immediate impact on the patient's dangerously high blood pressure. Think ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation), but in this case, 'C' involves immediate BP control.

mnemonic.title: HEAD-UP
mnemonic.expansion: Head up (elevate HOB), Evaluate (assess for triggers), Antihypertensives (prepare to administer), Determine (check catheter patency), Urgent (this is a medical emergency), Provider (notify the provider)
